Central themes of *kuleana* (responsibility) and *mana* (spiritual power) permeate the narrative, framed through the protagonist’s paradoxical physical diminutiveness and supernatural strength, a recurring motif in Hawaiian hero cycles. Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s birth mother, Pōkaʻi, and stepfather, Pualiʻi, anchor the story in the liminal spaces of *Ewa* and *Keahumoa*—places later marked by colonial erasure but here immortalized in the enduring toponyms of the *Nāmakaokapāoʻo* sweet potato fields. These fields, described in Paragraph 4 as cultivated by Pualiʻi yet attributed to the child’s name, reflect the recursive relationship between *ʻāina* (land) and *moʻolelo* (story) in Hawaiian cosmology, where narratives physically inscribe ancestral memory onto geography.  

The text’s cultural resonance hinges on its interplay between *kapu* (sacred prohibition) and *noa* (freedom from restriction). Paragraph 6’s violent confrontation, wherein Pualiʻi announces he will kill Nāmakaokapāoʻo to restore balance (“the day I will kill him… all will be noa”), echoes post-1819 shifts following the abolition of the *ʻai kapu* system. However, Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s death chant (Paragraph 7) invokes *Nāmakaokalani* and *Nāmakaokaiʻa*—figures embedded in the *kupuna* (ancestral) pantheon—asserting continuity with pre-contact cosmology. This duality suggests a layered narrative: one that acknowledges changing power structures while reaffirming the enduring authority of divine lineage.  

From a literary perspective, the story synthesizes *moʻolelo pule* (stories of divine intervention) with *moʻolelo aloha ʻāina* (proto-nationalist tales). Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s ascension to the ridgepole (Paragraph 11) symbolizes his elevation above human conflicts, physically aligning him with the *kumulāʻau* (ridgepole) as a metaphorical seat of leadership (*kūpuna piko*). The destruction of Puali’i’s forces and the final battle at Waikīkī (Paragraphs 12–14) resonate with ahupuaʻa-level assertions of sovereignty, where control of land (*Keahumoa*) and water (*Honouliuli*) becomes a metaphor for self-determination.  

Historically, the recitation of this tale in 19th–20th century Hawaiian-language newspapers aligns with a resurgence of *kanaka maoli* (Native Hawaiian) national consciousness amid colonial pressures. The story’s emphasis on a child hero whose strength stems from divine ancestry mirrors political anxieties of the 1890s, particularly the commodification of Hawaiian lands (e.g., sweet potato fields) by foreign settlers (Pualiʻi, a Līhuʻe fisherman turned agriculturalist) and the reclamation of that agency through ritual violence. Pualiʻi’s death by his own weapon, wielded by Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s marrow, could allegorize the instability of settler dominance in a land where ancestral bones literally fight back.  

Scholarship such as Rubellite Kawena Johnson’s analysis of *Naupaka* legends reveals similar fusion of sacred and profane in Hawaiian narrative cycles. Here, however, the absence of female agency beyond Pōkaʻi’s reproductive role (“her body is damaged,” Paragraph 3) underscores the patriarchal underpinnings of heroic tales, reflecting what C. Fred Bergsten terms “cumulative castration” in post-contact Hawaiian literature—a foreshadowing of the disenfranchisement of Kanaka women under missionary legal frameworks.  

Politically, the chapter’s fixation on Oʻahu’s control (“Oʻahu now fell entirely to Nāmakaokapāoʻo”) resurfaces during the 1893 overthrow, when Kahiki (foreign) forces sought to fragment island-based power structures. The story’s cyclical violence—eruptions of divine justice against transgressive authority—may have served as subtextually subversive rhetoric in Hawaiian-language nationalist newspapers, reinforcing indigenous sovereignty discourses.  

Ultimately, the text transcends mere folklore, functioning as a synecdoche of Hawaiian resistance—a reclaiming of space through symbolic violence, where place names become enduring acts of refusal to forget. Its survival in print media following the Kingdom’s violent dissolution attests to its utility as both *kīʻaha* (protective charm) and *hoʻokele* (navigational guide) for a people negotiating colonial erasure. The chapter’s enduring significance lies in its capacity to animate land as memory and heroism as ancestral covenant, weaponizing myth to defy historical amnesia.

– In Hawaiian cosmology, childbirth locations often symbolize the mana (spiritual power) of the land connecting to the child; ‘Ewa’s adjacency to sacred sites like Honouliuli beach may imply proximity to liminal or spiritually charged spaces.  

• **Narrative Structure and Cultural Norms**:  
– The act of *launa kino ai me ka moe ‘ana* (to lie together physically during cohabitation) euphemistically describes conception, a common literary device in mo‘olelo Hawai‘i. The phrasing avoids explicit sexual language, reflecting cultural taboos around reproduction for ali‘i (chiefs), who were often subject to strict *haʻu pī* (privacy laws) during mating rituals (*Peabody 1995:245-247*).  
– The separation of spouses (*ho‘i akula ‘o Kauluakaha‘i i kona ‘āina*) after conception mirrors practices among high-ranking couples. Elite women often gave birth in secluded *‘īni* (birthing huts) under the care of kāula (prophetesses) or kōkua (midwives), removing the birthing process from daily life to protect the infant’s *mana*.  

• **Name Etymologies and Symbolism**:  
– *Nāmakaokapāo‘o* (The Eyes of the Pāo‘o Fish): The *pāo‘o* (gudgeon fish) symbolizes keen vision and resilience in Hawaiian metaphor (*Pukui & Elbert 1977:340*), traits that foreshadow the child’s destructive-yet-strategic strength (see Ex. 3). The name’s focus on eyes (*maka*) and head (*pō* as “night” in Pōka‘ī’s name) later becomes central to the conflict with Puali‘i, who threatens to consume these body parts.  
– *Kauluakaha‘i* (The Inspiration of Kaha‘i): Kaha‘i is a legendary voyager and progenitor figure (*Ka-foo-li*, *Kalamai*) who traveled to Kahiki (Tahiti) and returned with breadfruit (*Pukui & Elbert 1977:385*). Kauluakaha‘i’s demigod status (*ali‘i nui* from Ex. 1) aligns him with transnational mythic traditions, positioning Nāmakaokapāo‘o as a liminal being bridging Hawaiian and Kahikinu‘u (foreign lands).  
– *Pōka‘i* (Night’s Resolve): The name combines *pō* (night, death, the unknown) and *ka‘i* (to lead or bear), hinting at her role as a prophetic figure who *leads through darkness*. Her later confrontation with Puali‘i (*Ex. 2-3*) reinforces this interplay of shadow and vision in the narrative.  

• **Childbirth as Allegory**:  
– The *‘ilihune* (extremely difficult) labor allegorizes the birth of new cultural paradigms. In ‘Ai Kapu traditions, childbirth for ali‘i was accompanied by prayers to *Haumea*, goddess of fertility, and rituals to ensure the child’s spiritual strength. The arduous birth of Nāmakaokapāo‘o may symbolize the *pain of transitioning away from ‘Ai Kapu practices*, as the child later embodies a rejection of these customs (*see Ex. 3*).  
– Kauluakaha‘i’s symbolic departure (“returned to his land”) and Pōka‘i’s solitary pregnancy reflect the duality of divine vs. mortal origins in demigod narratives. This mirrors the story of Pele’s birth, where her mother Haumea remains in one place while her father Tu-tapu travels.  

• **Cultural Continuity and Disruption**:  
– The mention of *Hō‘ae‘ae* and *‘Ewa* subtly critiques *‘ai kapu* territoriality. ‘Ewa was a district where *heiau* (temples) were abundant, yet Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s destructive acts (*Ex. 3*) later destabilize agricultural systems tied to these ritual spaces. The text here primes this disruption by rooting his conception in a liminal location.  
– The emphasis on *moe ‘ana* (sleeping/mating) without mention of *kīhei* (marriage rituals) may critique the fluidity of relationships under *‘ai kapu*, where alliances were often negotiated through unions but also subject to power imbalances (*Nonaka 2005*). Pōka‘ī’s agency in this process (carrying the child while her husband departs) reflects the gendered labor of propagating lineages.

**Paragraph 4:**  
• **Legacy in landscape:**  
– The survival of the sweet potato (*ʻuala*) fields of "Nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo" until the present underscores the protagonist’s enduring cultural and agricultural legacy. This aligns with the Hawaiian practice of *hoʻopaʻa inoa* (naming places after significant acts or people), where the boy’s early-life feat of cultivation becomes immortalized in topography.  
– The naming tradition (*ka inoa o ia mau māla*) reflects oral history’s role in preserving stories across generations, even as the protagonist’s name itself—Nāmakaokapāoʻo (Nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo, "The Eyes of the Demigod’s Fish")—alludes to his supernatural lineage (from a divine parent, likely Hema, a voyaging demigod associated with healing; see Pukui & Elbert, p. 138).  

• **ʻAi Kapu and food hierarchies:**  
– Pualiʻi’s declaration—"*Aia ā kālua ke poʻo o ka ulua me ka ʻuala*" ("When I have eaten the head of the ulua with the sweet potato")—reinforces the rigid rules of the *ʻai kapu* system, where certain foods (like the ulua fish) were ritually reserved for high-ranking males.  
– The *poʻo* (head) of the ulua represents the highest-status portion, reserved for the *kāne* (man) in *ʻai kapu* customs (Beckwith, *Hawaiian Mythology*, p. 256). Pualiʻi’s act of eating this portion symbolizes his assertion of *kapu* authority, contrasting with his later integration of Pōkaʻī (a woman) into the meal (*ʻai kāna wahine*), which subtly subverts norms by allowing her to share food prepared under his privilege.  

• **Honouliuli’s cultural resonance:**  
– Pualiʻi’s journey to *Honouliuli* ("Dark Bay") situates him in a mythologically charged location. Esteemed as a haunt of *ʻaumakua* (ancestral deities), Honouliuli was associated with Kamohoaliʻi, the great shark god who guided Pele’s canoe to Hawaiʻi (Malo, *Hawaiian Antiquities*, p. 102). His choice to fish here suggests a conscious engagement with ancestral power, perhaps to validate his threatened dominance over Nāmakaokapāoʻo.  
– The pairing of *ulua* (a large jack fish) and *ʻuala* (sweet potato) mirrors the symbolic tension in Example 3, where *ulua* substitutes human sacrifice. Here, though, the *ulua*’s "sacrifice" enables the *kāne*’s meal, while the *ʻuala*—a staple of commoners—sustains the wahine and others, reinforcing class divisions.  

• **Generational and ideological tension:**  
– This scene juxtaposes Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s lasting agricultural work (his fields endure "until today") with Pualiʻi’s transient consumption rituals. The boy’s *ʻuala* symbolizes sustenance and continuity, while Pualiʻi’s *ulua* hunt underscores the impermanence of male-dominated *kapu* systems.  
– The recurring reference to *ʻuala* may reflect the story’s embedded critique of *ʻai kapu*. Unlike taro (*kalo*), which was linked to the god Haloa and reserved for rituals (Pukui & Handy, *The Polynesian Family System*, p. 41), *ʻuala* (originating in Polynesia but not central to cosmogony) was more accessible to women and commoners. By focusing on *ʻuala*, the text might subtly valorize egalitarian practices over the *kapu* hierarchy.  

• **Name etymologies and divine echoes:**  
– *Nāmakaokapāoʻo*: The hybridization of *nā maka* ("the eyes") with *pāoʻo* (a fish or "head") mirrors the boy’s demigod status. In mythology, eyes (*maka*) often symbolize spiritual sight (e.g., Namaka’s sister Pele’s volcanic "eyes"), while the *pāoʻo* fish (a wrasse or goatfish) connects to *ʻaumakua* like Lono and Kanaloa, gods associated with farming and voyaging.  
– *Honouliuli*: The name’s referent to darkness (*uli*) and connotation of spiritual potency aligns with its role as a site of shark divinities, linking Pualiʻi’s fishing to mythic precedents where humans petitioned gods for sustenance.

This was the *kā i mua*...”);  • The description of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o as a pre malo-wearing child contradicts the maturity and  leadership he demonstrates by his actions and  cognitive skills, where he tells his friends to destroy  the garden. The hesitancy of the children, and their depiction in this story as indecisive and timid could be a   Protestant Christian bias (post-1820). The idea of  not pulling out the sweet potato tubers from the  ground could represent not entirely eliminating the  Hawaiian people/culture in the Christian era (not a  complete genocide) despite the biases against the  ‘Ai Kapu;

Unlike earlier *AI Kapu* rituals where *ulua* substituted as sacrificial offerings, this threatens literal human sacrifice—a regression to archaic practices. The narrative positions Pua-li‘i as a figure clinging to pre-contact *kapu* extremism, while Nāmaka-o-ka-pāo‘o embodies post-‘Ai Kapu resistance through defiant prayer.  
• **Etymological analysis**:  
  – *Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o* (“Eyes of the stick/gourd”) and *Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o* are variations of the same name, with *pāo‘o* (either “stick” or a ritual vessel) reinforced by metaphorical “head” (po‘o) in the chant (see previous footnote on *maka* in Example 3).  
  – *Nā-kukui-‘ai-maka-o-kalani* (The-one-spared-by-heaven’s-light-sacred-eyes) and *Kukui-‘ai-maka-o-kalani* (Heaven’s-light-sacred-eyes-food) invoke *kukui* (candlenut/illumination) and deified ancestor *maka* (eyes) as protective forces, contrasting with the destructive *maka* in Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s name.  
• **Chant analysis (pule make)**:  
  – The chant layers prophecy and defiance. Lines “E waiho paha Nākukui‘aimakaokalani” and “O ku‘u wahi aikāne kēia” reference divine intervention via *kukui* (light of ancestors) and *aikāne* (same-sex bond, a motif in Hawaiian divine relationships, e.g., Lā‘au and Wahieloa).  
  – “E he‘e lā, e he‘e ka hōhē wale” evokes oceanic imagery, suggesting that while fish (*he‘e*, octopus) may flee, *hōhē* (filth/evil) must also depart, symbolizing Puali‘i’s violence cleansing itself.  
  – The conclusion shifts from plural combat imagery (kanaka + ihe; ihe + pahu) to singular death (*make*), implying Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s spiritual victory even if physically slain.  
• **Cultural allegory**:  
  – The four sweet potatoes (*‘au ‘uala ehā*) echo the mythical number *4* in mo‘olelo, often symbolizing quadrants (e.g., four winds, four royal lines). Their roasting precedes ritual consumption, mirroring *AI Kapu’s* structure, but Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s chant transforms it into a cosmological appeal.  
  – The children fleeing (“nā keiki a pau loa”) reflects historical trauma: post-contact society’s youth rejecting violent traditions, foreshadowing the eventual abolition of *AI Kapu* in 1819.
